## About this course

:::: {.columns}

**What we'll learn:**

- Data visualization with ggplot2
- Data transformation with dplyr

## Why data science for psychology?

Psychology research involves:

- Collecting data from experiments, surveys, observations
- Cleaning messy real-world data
- Visualizing patterns and relationships
- Communicating findings clearly

. . .

**Data science gives us tools to do all of this better.**

## The old way vs. the new way

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Point-and-click (SPSS, Excel)**

- Hard to reproduce
- Error-prone
- Limited visualizations
- Doesn't scale
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Code-based (R)**

- Fully reproducible
- Transparent & shareable
- Unlimited customization
- Handles any data size
:::
::::

## Why R specifically?

- **Free and open source** â€” no expensive licenses
- **Designed for statistics** â€” built by statisticians for data analysis
- **Massive community** â€” packages for everything
- **Psychology-friendly** â€” `psych`, `lavaan`, `lme4`, `brms`...
- **Beautiful visualizations** â€” ggplot2 is industry-leading
- **Reproducible research** â€” Quarto/RMarkdown integration

# Getting set up {background-color="#2c3e50"}

## What you need to install

1. **R** â€” the programming language
   - Download from [cloud.r-project.org](https://cloud.r-project.org)

2. **RStudio** â€” the interface we'll use to write R
   - Download from [posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop](https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/)

. . .

::: {.callout-important}
Install R **first**, then RStudio. RStudio needs R to work!
:::

## R vs RStudio

Think of it like this:

- **R** is the engine of a car
- **RStudio** is the dashboard, steering wheel, and GPS

You *could* drive with just an engine... but why would you?

## The RStudio interface

![](img/rstudio-panes.png){fig-alt="RStudio interface showing four panes" width="80%"}

::: {.notes}
The four panes: Source (top-left), Console (bottom-left), Environment (top-right), Files/Plots/Help (bottom-right)
:::

## The four panes

| Pane | What it does |
|------|--------------|
| **Source** (top-left) | Write and edit your code files |
| **Console** (bottom-left) | Run code interactively, see output |
| **Environment** (top-right) | See your data and objects |
| **Files/Plots/Help** (bottom-right) | Navigate files, view plots, get help |

```{r}

```

```{r}
#| eval: true
```

## More console experiments

```{r}
# R can do math
10 * 5
sqrt(144)
```

```{r}
# R has built-in functions
```

## The assignment operator

In R, we use `<-` to assign values to objects:
```{r}
x <- 10
```

Think of it as an arrow pointing left: "put 10 into x"

. . .

::: {.callout-tip}
**Keyboard shortcut:** Alt + - (Windows) or Option + - (Mac)
:::

# Projects & workflow {background-color="#2c3e50"}

## Why use RStudio Projects?

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Without projects:**

- Files scattered everywhere
- `setwd()` nightmares
- "It works on my computer"
- Lost work when switching tasks
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**With projects:**

- Everything in one folder
- Paths just work
- Share the whole folder
- Easy to switch between projects
:::
::::

## Creating a project

1. File â†’ New Project...
2. Choose "New Directory" â†’ "New Project"
3. Name it (e.g., "psy410")
4. Pick a location (Documents folder is fine)
5. Click "Create Project"

. . .

You'll see a `.Rproj` file appear â€” this is your project file.

## Project folder structure

A good project folder might look like:

```
psy410/
â”œâ”€â”€ psy410.Rproj
â”œâ”€â”€ data/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ survey_data.csv
â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ analysis.R
â””â”€â”€ output/
    â””â”€â”€ figures/
```

Keep your work organized from the start!

## R Scripts

R scripts (`.R` files) are where you write and save your code.

To create one:

1. File â†’ New File â†’ R Script
2. Or press Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + N

. . .

**Always save your scripts!** The console history disappears.

## Running code from a script

- **Run one line:** Put cursor on line, press Ctrl/Cmd + Enter
- **Run selection:** Highlight code, press Ctrl/Cmd + Enter
- **Run entire script:** Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + Enter

. . .

::: {.callout-tip}
You'll use Ctrl/Cmd + Enter constantly. Memorize it!
:::

## Comments

Use `#` to write comments â€” notes for yourself and others:

```{r}
# This calculates the mean age of participants
mean_age <- mean(ages)

# Anything after # is ignored by R
x <- 10  # this assigns 10 to x
```

Comments are essential. Your future self will thank you.

# Your first real task {background-color="#2c3e50"}

## Installing packages

R's power comes from **packages** â€” bundles of functions others have written.

```{r}
# Install a package (do this once)
install.packages("tidyverse")
```

```{r}
# Load a package (do this every session)
library(tidyverse)
```

## The tidyverse

The `tidyverse` is actually a collection of packages:

| Package | Purpose |
|---------|---------|
| `ggplot2` | Data visualization |
| `dplyr` | Data manipulation |
| `tidyr` | Data tidying |
| `readr` | Reading data files |
| `tibble` | Modern data frames |
| `stringr` | String manipulation |
| `forcats` | Working with factors |
| `purrr` | Functional programming |

We'll use most of these throughout the course.

## Let's look at some data

After loading tidyverse, you have access to built-in datasets:

```{r}
#| eval: true
#| echo: true
library(tidyverse)

# mpg is a dataset about fuel economy
glimpse(mpg)
```

# Getting help {background-color="#2c3e50"}

## When you're stuck

1. **Use `?`** â€” e.g., `?mean` opens the help page
2. **Google it** â€” seriously, everyone does this
3. **Stack Overflow** â€” most R questions are answered there
4. **R4DS book** â€” [r4ds.hadley.nz](https://r4ds.hadley.nz)
5. **Ask me** â€” that's what I'm here for!

## Reading help pages

```{r}
?mean
```

Help pages include:

- **Description** â€” what the function does
- **Usage** â€” how to call it
- **Arguments** â€” what inputs it takes
- **Examples** â€” working code you can run

The examples section is gold â€” run them!

## Error messages

Errors will happen. A lot. That's normal.

```{r}
#| error: true
#| eval: true
# This will error - can you spot why?
maen(c(1, 2, 3))
```

. . .

Read the error message carefully â€” R is trying to help you.
